Multiple Roots

  1. Problem:
    Newton’s method and the Secant method will generally give problems if when .

  2. Zeros and their Multiplicity:

  3. Identifying Simple Zeros:

    • Generalization of Theorem 2.11:

      The result in Theorem 2.12 implies that an interval about p exists where Newton’s method converges quadratically to p for any initial approximation , provided that p is a simple zero.

  4. Why Simple Zeros:
    Quadratic convergence might not occur if the zero is not simple

    Example: Let Notice that Newton’s method with converges to the zero but not quadratically

  5. Handling the problem of multiple roots:
    We Modify Newton’s Method
    We define as:

    Derivation can be found here!

    • Properties:
      • If g has the required continuity conditions, functional iteration applied to will be quadratically convergent regardless of the multiplicity of the zero of .
      • Theoretically, the only drawback to this method is the additional calculation of and the more laborious procedure of calculating the iterates.
      • In practice, multiple roots can cause serious round-off problems because the denominator of (2.13) consists of the difference of two numbers that are both close to 0.
      • In the case of a simple zero the original Newton’s method requires substantially less computation.
